added_lines: from novaclient import exceptions as nova_exceptions host_ids, _ = self._pick_hosts(reservation) return host_ids def _pick_hosts(self, reservation): self._validate_reservation_params(reservation) resource_request, resource_traits, source_flavor = \ self._get_flavor_details(flavor_id) # return just enough hosts to satisfy the request while len(candidates) > req_amount: candidates.pop() host_ids = [host['id'] for host in candidates] return host_ids, source_flavor def _validate_reservation_params(self, values): marshall_attributes = set([ 'amount', 'flavor_id', 'affinity', 'start_date', 'end_date', ]) missing_attr = marshall_attributes - set(values.keys()) if missing_attr: raise mgr_exceptions.MissingParameter(param=','.join(missing_attr)) try: values['amount'] = strutils.validate_integer( values['amount'], "amount", 1, db_api.DB_MAX_INT) except ValueError as e: raise mgr_exceptions.MalformedParameter(str(e)) resource_request = {} resource_traits = {} return (resource_request, resource_traits, source_flavor) host_ids, source_flavor = self._pick_hosts(values) instance_reservation_val = { 'reservation_id': reservation_id, # use flavor display values, # even though we probably reserve different resources 'vcpus': source_flavor["vcpus"], 'memory_mb': source_flavor["ram"], 'disk_gb': source_flavor["disk"], 'amount': values['amount'], 'affinity': None, 'resource_properties': json.dumps(source_flavor) } instance_reservation = db_api.instance_reservation_create( instance_reservation_val) for host_id in host_ids: db_api.host_allocation_create({'compute_host_id': host_id, 'reservation_id': reservation_id}) try: flavor_id, aggregate_id = \ self._create_resources(instance_reservation) except nova_exceptions.ClientException: LOG.exception("Failed to create Nova resources " "for reservation %s", reservation_id) self._cleanup_resources(instance_reservation) raise mgr_exceptions.NovaClientError() db_api.instance_reservation_update(instance_reservation['id'], {'flavor_id': flavor_id, 'aggregate_id': aggregate_id}) return instance_reservation['id'] def _create_resources(self, instance_reservation): # TODO(johngarbutt) implement this! return None, None def _cleanup_resources(self, instance_reservation): # TODO(johngarbutt) implement this! pass

commit_message:
Implement allocation_candidates for flavor plugin

This adds the flavor plugin, where users request
a reservation similar to:

  openstack reservation lease create test --reservation \
    resource_type=flavor:instance,amount=2,\
    flavor_id='e26a4241-b83d-4516-8e0e-8ce2665d1966'

This uses lots of ideas from the instance reservation
plugin, and where possible leans on some of the existing
logic, currently only filter_hosts_by_reservation.

The plugin is not currently useable.
There are follow on patches that implement
reserve_resource and then finally update_reservation.

Change-Id: I7507e87908e16b313fd624810d6f43cb73dddafe

commit_message:
[kolla] Kayobe RC1 and branch cut for 2024.1 Caracal

This release patch is to ensure, that trailing typed projects have been
branched for 2024.1 Caracal. The deadline for these deliverables is
June 6th, 2024.

Please +1 if the team is ready for us to proceed with this or update/-1
if something should be changed.

Change-Id: I708a6d0edc82c16157c2281a45b749999babdc40

commit_message:
Remove old excludes

These are detected as errors since the clean up was done[1] in
the requirements repository. Minimum versions are bumped to avoid
installing these known bad versions.

[1] 314734e938f107cbd5ebcc7af4d9167c11347406

Also remove the note about old pip's behavior because resolver in
recent pip does not require specific order.

Change-Id: I04335dd0d06b5c65b805fbb1e0fc0cd1c10a79fb

subject: Fix dynamic pollsters on compute nodes and coordination process
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-03-25 16:39:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/cc10788389b974f31694c1747b29ef7e99c39626', 'message': 'Fix dynamic pollsters on compute nodes and coordination process

Ceilometer can coordinate Pollsters based on the discovery process. The
idea (according to what we have in the code so far) is that the values
"discovered" by the discoveries are bound/linked to a discovery agent.
Then, only the pollsters on the node where these agents run are the ones
being able to process, as the code will only enable pollster to gather
data if the discovery returns some data to feed the pollsters.

Some pollsters, such as the Dynamic pollster system for non-OpenStack
API and for compute nodes do not depend on the discovery process. Thus,
they rely on a "local" node discovery process that fakes the discovery
and always returns a fixed value.

The problem in this situation is that multiple Dynamic pollsters in the
compute nodes are coordinated based on the discovery which is always the
same. Therefore, only one of them is going to execute. As a consequence
of that, data will be lost.

To address this situation we have an approach to make the local node
discovery return a unique "resource" based on the node where it runs.
Furthermore, we are introducing a process that will enable the
coordination of pollsters themselves.

Change-Id: I2a0a3bc17bc3a6d78e1629fd0a460d75589025dd

commit_message:
Fix dynamic pollsters on compute nodes and coordination process

Ceilometer can coordinate Pollsters based on the discovery process. The
idea (according to what we have in the code so far) is that the values
"discovered" by the discoveries are bound/linked to a discovery agent.
Then, only the pollsters on the node where these agents run are the ones
being able to process, as the code will only enable pollster to gather
data if the discovery returns some data to feed the pollsters.

Some pollsters, such as the Dynamic pollster system for non-OpenStack
API and for compute nodes do not depend on the discovery process. Thus,
they rely on a "local" node discovery process that fakes the discovery
and always returns a fixed value.

The problem in this situation is that multiple Dynamic pollsters in the
compute nodes are coordinated based on the discovery which is always the
same. Therefore, only one of them is going to execute. As a consequence
of that, data will be lost.

To address this situation we have an approach to make the local node
discovery return a unique "resource" based on the node where it runs.
Furthermore, we are introducing a process that will enable the
coordination of pollsters themselves.

Change-Id: I2a0a3bc17bc3a6d78e1629fd0a460d75589025dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/17/914117/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.conf = service.prepare_service([], []) self.discovery = localnode.LocalNodeDiscovery(self.conf) self.assertEqual([self.conf.host], self.discovery.discover(self.manager))
deleted_lines: CONF = service.prepare_service([], []) self.discovery = localnode.LocalNodeDiscovery(CONF) self.assertEqual(['local_host'], self.discovery.discover(self.manager))

commit_message:
Bump Ansible version for tests repo

Current Ansible version for tests repo, which is used for functional
tests can not deal with some more modern logic, causing CI to fail
for Ubuntu Jammy on apt_package_pinning for Galera role.

Updating Ansible version fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I70838dc4fb1cadfcf579b5e9af5769a8f48108da

commit_message:
Add type annotations

Add type annotations to the different parameters
and return values to modernize the python used.
This will also introduce mypy as another tool
for static code analysis which will currently not
run in CI

commit_message:
Fix leak of ports on share server deletion

- Manila share server deletion happens asynchronously. If deletion of
share server fails in between, share server network ports remained as
it is. So we should better delete share network ports first and then
continue share server deletion.
- It may be possible, that there are ports existing without a
corresponding manila network allocation entry in the manila db, because
port create request may have been successfully sent to neutron, but not
stored in db. So query(and delete) those from neutron after db entries
are deleted.

Closes-bug: #2067266
Change-Id: Id86dade1194494e599aea9adad06e4ca6cb119b6
(cherry picked from commit 76d032969848fa409f3b7da499cc2da3de67f6be)
(cherry picked from commit 19622387dc54ed2458bc514854e742160954318c)

commit_message:
DNM: mypy improvements

- add a job
- switch from include to exclude list
- don't follow imports (to avoid checking for excluded modules)
- don't require type definitions for functions
- add mypy to default tox target list

Change-Id: I3c198c1695852cc7b99b08e2e49485b3a02e5bc7

commit_message:
mypy: enable checks for all __init__.py files

Some of the files imported from libraries with no py.typed markers.
Hence disabling import-untyped errors for the repo.

Change-Id: I285d7bfffd9349467b24d8f078847d77a5b47cbe

commit_message:
Run Notify part when RPC is disabled

Previously a logic to skip RPC configuration was added, however, our
Notify logic depends solely on being different from RPC while not
taking into account that RPC might be skipped as a whole.

We extend Notify logic with rules to run Notify part when RPC is not
intended to be configured.

Change-Id: Ib23bc98de8fb8e9dde1a7cb4512913b2545c276b

commit_message:
Configure Cinder to use new audit middleware testing class

Updated Cinder to use the new Keystone Audit Middleware testing class
in zaza-openstack-tests rather than the previous hardcoded functional
tests. This provides more flexibility and resiliency in the functional
testing of charms using the audit middleware feature.

func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/1212
Change-Id: I63192c7db128e3d640e33911d8507cafddc3d5a0

commit_message:
Add support for the 'cpu_models' option in nova.conf

Since OpenStack Train release the 'cpu_models' config option
has superseded the 'cpu_model' config option in the nova.conf.
This patch adds support for the new 'cpu_models' allowing a user
to provide a comma separated list of supported, named CPU models.

This patch also includes a unit test for the cpu_mode='custom'.

Closes-bug: #2025914
Change-Id: I30328abc07d3304f1bfb67c81360fb5229214c97
(cherry picked from commit b57593f86dc0627d74a9264a9035a2c67fd69c01)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute refs/changes/23/917723/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @patch.object(context.uuid, 'uuid4') def test_libvirt_cpu_mode_custom_model(self, mock_uuid): self.test_config.set('cpu-mode', 'custom') self.test_config.set('cpu-model', 'Broadwell') self.lsb_release.return_value = {'DISTRIB_CODENAME': 'bionic'} mock_uuid.return_value = 'e46e530d-18ae-4a67-9ff0-e6e2ba7c60a7' libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_mode'], 'custom') self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_model'], 'Broadwell') # should be ignored self.test_config.set('cpu-mode', 'host-model') self.test_config.set('cpu-model', 'Haswell') libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertNotIn('cpu-model', libvirt()) @patch.object(context.uuid, 'uuid4') def test_libvirt_cpu_mode_custom_models(self, mock_uuid): self.test_config.set('cpu-mode', 'custom') self.test_config.set('cpu-models', 'SandyBridge,IvyBridge,Haswell,Broadwell') self.lsb_release.return_value = {'DISTRIB_CODENAME': 'bionic'} mock_uuid.return_value = 'e46e530d-18ae-4a67-9ff0-e6e2ba7c60a7' libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_mode'], 'custom') self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_models'], 'SandyBridge,IvyBridge,Haswell,Broadwell') # should be ignored self.test_config.set('cpu-model', 'Haswell') libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertNotIn('cpu_model', libvirt())

commit_message:
Add support for the 'cpu_models' option in nova.conf

Since OpenStack Train release the 'cpu_models' config option
has superseded the 'cpu_model' config option in the nova.conf.
This patch adds support for the new 'cpu_models' allowing a user
to provide a comma separated list of supported, named CPU models.

This patch also includes a unit test for the cpu_mode='custom'.

Closes-bug: #2025914
Change-Id: I30328abc07d3304f1bfb67c81360fb5229214c97
(cherry picked from commit b57593f86dc0627d74a9264a9035a2c67fd69c01)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute refs/changes/22/917722/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @patch.object(context.uuid, 'uuid4') def test_libvirt_cpu_mode_custom_model(self, mock_uuid): self.test_config.set('cpu-mode', 'custom') self.test_config.set('cpu-model', 'Broadwell') self.lsb_release.return_value = {'DISTRIB_CODENAME': 'bionic'} mock_uuid.return_value = 'e46e530d-18ae-4a67-9ff0-e6e2ba7c60a7' libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_mode'], 'custom') self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_model'], 'Broadwell') # should be ignored self.test_config.set('cpu-mode', 'host-model') self.test_config.set('cpu-model', 'Haswell') libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertNotIn('cpu-model', libvirt()) @patch.object(context.uuid, 'uuid4') def test_libvirt_cpu_mode_custom_models(self, mock_uuid): self.test_config.set('cpu-mode', 'custom') self.test_config.set('cpu-models', 'SandyBridge,IvyBridge,Haswell,Broadwell') self.lsb_release.return_value = {'DISTRIB_CODENAME': 'bionic'} mock_uuid.return_value = 'e46e530d-18ae-4a67-9ff0-e6e2ba7c60a7' libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_mode'], 'custom') self.assertEqual(libvirt()['cpu_models'], 'SandyBridge,IvyBridge,Haswell,Broadwell') # should be ignored self.test_config.set('cpu-model', 'Haswell') libvirt = context.NovaComputeLibvirtContext() self.assertNotIn('cpu_model', libvirt())

subject: Threads to process pollsters
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-02-26 12:25:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/068ea6b0f770a0afe499afda89bab94c52469508', 'message': 'Threads to process pollsters

The pollsters in Ceilometer are grouped in "sources" (A.K.A "polling
task"); normally, people group pollsters in "sources" by interval, for
instance, putting together all pollsters that should gather data every
10 minutes, and so on. On the other hand, some other people configure
the "sources" to represent a polling context, such as, all pollsters
that collect data from instances together, then all pollsters that
collect data from routers, then load balancers, RadosGW, and so on.

The "sources" definition, are all processed in their own thread.
Therefore, "sources" are processed in parallel. On the other hand, the
pollsters inside the "sources" are processed in a serial fashion in the
same thread. This can be a problem, if a "source" has many pollsters,
and their data collection and processing takes a while to finish.

Of course, one can take it to extreme, and configure only one pollster
per "source". However, that is not a very interesting solution, and
would make the configuration a bit odd.

This patch proposes a configuration to enable operators to define the
number of threads to use when processing pollsters of a "source". The
value one (1) means that the processing is in a serial fashion (not
ordered!). The value zero (0) means that the we will use as much threads
as the number of pollsters configured in the polling task. Any other
positive integer can be used to fix an upper bound limi to the number of
threads used for processing pollsters in parallel. One must bear in mind
that, using more than one thread might not take full advantage of the
discovery cache and pollsters cache processes; it is possible though to
improve/use pollsters that synchronize themselves in the cache objects.

Change-Id: I80b2f18a70cea1ab6e31b37e75ac93ee897e6cb4

commit_message:
Threads to process pollsters

The pollsters in Ceilometer are grouped in "sources" (A.K.A "polling
task"); normally, people group pollsters in "sources" by interval, for
instance, putting together all pollsters that should gather data every
10 minutes, and so on. On the other hand, some other people configure
the "sources" to represent a polling context, such as, all pollsters
that collect data from instances together, all pollsters that collect
data from routers, load balancers, RadosGW, and so on.

The "sources" definition, are all processed in their own thread.
Therefore, "sources" are processed in parallel. On the other hand, the
pollsters inside the "sources" are processed in a serial fashion in the
same thread. This can be a problem, if a "source" has many pollsters,
and their data collection and processing takes a while to finish.

Of course, one can take it to the extreme, and configure only one
pollster per "source". However, that is not a very interesting
solution, and would make the configuration a bit odd.

This patch proposes a configuration to enable operators to define the
number of threads to use when processing pollsters of a "source". The
value one (1) means that the processing is in a serial fashion (not
ordered!). The value zero (0) means that we will use as much threads
as the number of pollsters configured in the polling task. Any other
positive integer can be used to fix an upper bound limit to the number of
threads used for processing pollsters in parallel. One must bear in mind
that, using more than one thread might not take full advantage of the
discovery cache and pollsters cache processes; it is possible though to
improve/use/develop pollsters that synchronize themselves in the cache objects.

Change-Id: I80b2f18a70cea1ab6e31b37e75ac93ee897e6cb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/25/910225/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: LOG.debug.assert_called_with( 'Skip pollster %(name)s, no %(p_context)s resources found this ' 'cycle', {'name': pollster.name, 'p_context': ''}) LOG.debug.assert_called_with( 'Skip pollster %(name)s, no %(p_context)s resources found this ' 'cycle', {'name': 'test', 'p_context': 'new '})

commit_message:
Define region and interface for collector/fetcher

It appears, that produced gnocchiclient does not respect region_name
from the auth_section, thus it needs to be defined directly for the
fetcher.

We align collector for now with fetcher, to make change backportable.

Closes-Bug: #2067084
Change-Id: If3a37b6190449e18446e65ce3b8cb70cd9038c37
(cherry picked from commit fae91db568637021438ffe436fb935a6735feb66)

commit_message:
Evalute adding serial decorator to tests

Change-Id: Icb56caf688b20c02822d19484acbed54a9162535
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/whitebox-tempest-plugin refs/changes/39/916639/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest.lib import decorators@decorators.serial

subject: [RFE] [OVN] - IPv6 Distributed routing
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-12-13 14:01:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ad69f6ee69578175f66fe8cd1345d71f4c445630', 'message': '[WIP] [RFE] [OVN] - IPv6 Distributed routing

Added the new NAT rule for the IPv6 GUA addresses that are allocated to VMs.
The ovn-controller running on the chassis needs this rule to start responding
GARPs (IPv4 - FIP) and neighbor advertisements (for IPv6) [1].

The chassis that has the IPv6 GUA address associated with a NAT rule will be
able to send/receive traffic without the need to centralize it through the
chassis where the router resides.

This patch implement the IPv6 DVR behaviour when enabled via [ovn] section in
ml2_conf.ini file -> enable_distributed_ipv6 = True

For VMs already created before enabling this flag, neutron will notify in the
log about the config differences when it is restarted.
The NAT rules for IPv6 GUA will be automatically applied when executing a
SYNC_MODE_REPAIR.

[1]-
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2022-December/052126.html

Closes-Bug: #1998609
Change-Id: I2ac871cc1fe2423c9481ef765ad1cf1e00354fc6

'}, {'number': 21, 'created': '2023-05-30 19:36:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/76f9496ddfae9f4da8bd9cf9b0491b7dc970b6d3', 'message': '[RFE] [OVN] - IPv6 Distributed routing

Added the new NAT rule for the IPv6 GUA addresses that are allocated to
VMs. The ovn-controller running on the chassis needs this rule to start
responding GARPs (IPv4 - FIP) and neighbor advertisements (for IPv6) [1].

The chassis that has the IPv6 GUA address associated with a NAT rule
will be able to send/receive traffic without the need to centralize it
through the chassis where the router resides.

This patch implement the IPv6 DVR behaviour when enabled via [ovn]
section in ml2_conf.ini file -> enable_distributed_ipv6 = True

For VMs already created before enabling this flag, neutron will notify
in the log about the config differences when it is restarted. The NAT
rules for IPv6 GUA will be automatically applied when executing a
SYNC_MODE_REPAIR.

[1]
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2022-December/052126.html

Closes-Bug: #1998609
Change-Id: I2ac871cc1fe2423c9481ef765ad1cf1e00354fc6

commit_message:
[RFE] [OVN] - IPv6 Distributed routing

Added the new NAT rule for the IPv6 GUA addresses that are allocated to
VMs. The ovn-controller running on the chassis needs this rule to start
responding GARPs (IPv4 - FIP) and neighbor advertisements (for IPv6) [1].

The chassis that has the IPv6 GUA address associated with a NAT rule
will be able to send/receive traffic without the need to centralize it
through the chassis where the router resides.

This patch implement the IPv6 DVR behaviour when enabled via [ovn]
section in ml2_conf.ini file -> enable_distributed_ipv6 = True

For VMs already created before enabling this flag, neutron will notify
in the log about the config differences when it is restarted. The NAT
rules for IPv6 GUA will be automatically applied when executing a
SYNC_MODE_REPAIR.

[1]
https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-discuss/2022-December/052126.html

Closes-Bug: #1998609
Change-Id: I2ac871cc1fe2423c9481ef765ad1cf1e00354fc6

commit_message:
[api-ref] Add note about no validation of the target_tenant in RBAC API

Neutron can't really validate if string provided as 'target_tenant' in
the /v2.0/rbac-policies POST/PUT request is project ID or something
else, like e.g. project's name.
This patch adds small note about this to the Neutron api-ref document so
that users can be more aware of that.

Related-Bug: #2065743
Change-Id: Ie5bec404c372209ca15e4c8454957040032751cb

commit_message:
Allow openstack_hosts role to configure git safe.directory entries

This is defaulted to '*" and will be undefined when a CI specific
override is subsequently merged to the openstack-ansible repository.

Change-Id: I1c1dc35d8d59db4ae2b6770a620d91548a8a3734
(cherry picked from commit a8d1c8268a252cd7cc5ff0ec0988b75277a0a5fe)

commit_message:
Load nf_conntrack at boot time

Sysctl rules fined in charm config fails to be
applied in ovn enviroments because the rules are
applied before nf_conntrack is loaded.

By adding nf_conntrack to the /etc/modules file
it guarantees that it will be loaded before the
rules are applied.

Closes-Bug: #1922778
Change-Id: I51dae65cdc06e35230160bcaedda99710a72617d
(cherry picked from commit 389d2b7cb151321a518bc04a3578cb0f35c5577d)
(cherry picked from commit 6e75248816e3c01a9971ce33c4b4a013d69a0318)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute refs/changes/91/921291/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import yamlfrom charmhelpers.core.kernel import modprobe ensure_nf_conntrack_module_loaded(sysctl_settings)def ensure_nf_conntrack_module_loaded(sysctl_str): """Loads and writes nf_conntrack to /etc/modules if present in sysctls.""" # abort if empty or container if not sysctl_str or is_container(): return try: sysctl_dict = yaml.safe_load(sysctl_str) except yaml.YAMLError: log("Error parsing YAML sysctl_dict: {}".format(sysctl_str), level=ERROR) return if any("nf_conntrack" in key for key in sysctl_dict.keys()): try: # this call loads the module and writes an entry in /etc/modules # for automatic loading at early boot modprobe("nf_conntrack") except Exception as e: log("Failed to load or persist nf_conntrack" " kernel module: {}".format(e), level=WARNING)

The up scripts of the interface files were called only when the
interface moved from down to up, it means that they were not called
during the update of the configuration of an interface. So if during an
update, if an ipv6 subnet was plugged while the ipv4 subnet was already

Closes-Bug: #2037943

Change-Id: Iad78de1764bc3a3f699b5feef9e58999d2efe613
(cherry picked from commit 5c051a6ab6604c0cc38d59e1fdc0e6b199ed9932)
(cherry picked from commit 1f38d29b20f0769774517ae95d7d46c2eaff3265)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix incorrect masquerade rules in multivip LBs

The up scripts of the interface files were called only when the
interface moved from down to up, it means that they were not called
during the update of the configuration of an interface. So if during an
update, if an ipv6 subnet was plugged while the ipv4 subnet was already
there, the up script that sets the masquerade rules was not called.

It broke connectivity for either ipv4 or ipv6 between the client and the
members in UDP listeners in multivip load balancers.

Closes-Bug: #2037943

Change-Id: Iad78de1764bc3a3f699b5feef9e58999d2efe613
(cherry picked from commit 5c051a6ab6604c0cc38d59e1fdc0e6b199ed9932)
(cherry picked from commit 1f38d29b20f0769774517ae95d7d46c2eaff3265)

commit_message:
Fix horizon distro installation for EL

RDO is installing Horizon not under site-packages, but under /usr/share
which makes it completely different logic, with default horizon-manage
not working, as it can not import openstack_dashboard now, as

Change-Id: I4c06b4b5a206b087a9fce856f5fec936e058e3f8
(cherry picked from commit 25047cd99744190d923ecb1d81913e8a16d41e13)

In the previous patch, we did account for the MTU showing up
in the external IDs however the code only sets it if it's using
a remote managed port binding.  This code instead sets the binding

Related-Change-Id: I7ff300e9634e5e3fc68d70540392109fd8b9babc

Change-Id: I0653c83c5fb595847bb61182223db39b2f7e98c6

commit_message:
fix(ovn): set mtu in external_ids correctly

In the previous patch, we did account for the MTU showing up
in the external IDs however the code only sets it if it's using
a remote managed port binding.  This code instead sets the binding
for all the inerface types instead.

Related-Change-Id: I7ff300e9634e5e3fc68d70540392109fd8b9babc
Closes-Bug: 2053274
Change-Id: I0653c83c5fb595847bb61182223db39b2f7e98c6

deleted_lines: port_net = self._plugin.get_network( context, port['network_id']) mtu = str(port_net['mtu'])

simply build on top of the older ones. By changing the DNS extension to

be activated:

- dns-integration (already included)
- dns-domain-ports (the previous default extension)

are enabled, and allow me to make use of the two new features.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/user/neutron-integration.html

commit_message:
Enable more recent DNS extensions (dns-integration-domain-keywords)

Since yoga, there have been two "additions" to the DNS extensions, which
simply build on top of the older ones. By changing the DNS extension to
be the latest (dns-integration-domain-keywords), all 4 extensions will
be activated:

- dns-integration (already included)
- dns-domain-ports (the previous default extension)
- subnet-dns-publish-fixed-ip
- dns-integration-domain-keywords

These extensions are required to enable replacement of keywords in DNS
entries and allow publishing fixed IPs without restrictions [1].

I have tested this on a local cluster and confirmed that the extensions
are enabled, and allow me to make use of the two new features.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/user/neutron-integration.html

Closes-Bug: #2028163
Change-Id: I245cfe2f8fdb4d8ca325ade0c22771efa31b4bf2
(cherry picked from commit 3432ae7f02deb274aa222443faf83ce662bbaefc)

commit_message:
Use global wsgi subinterpreter for horizon mod_wsgi

Some cryptography is implemented in Rust and used
via PyO3 which does not support multiple subinterpreters.
See https://github.com/PyO3/pyo3/issues/576

Change-Id: Iff43e99134f41b65b220765a161fdd1b94495272

commit_message:
Drop default policy file location

With master version of Gnocchi[1], default policy file is no longer provided
since all policies are currently stored in code.

Moreover, it's long due to switch policy formats to YAML instead of
json.

[1] https://github.com/gnocchixyz/gnocchi/commit/6ad4bb8e62f2ab6f5e80e94d0e055a748f914561

Change-Id: Ie7923f3b1fa3fcf3f463b476f908be09533e103a
(cherry picked from commit 8c503a40c19d548d47b76331150aa5cba99f0112)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_gnocchi refs/changes/84/921284/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-05-16 12:59:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5b50044cdeff2e8cec184946ff8e68afaf35a7a0', 'message': "Use transient systemd units in Process fixture

to those used in a real deployment. It creates a systemd unit for each
daemon on the fly and combines all daemons of the same host in a systemd
slice. The units are automatically removed on service shutdown.

This also better ensures that there are no left over processes after
failed test cases as all processes started in a systemd unit are cleaned

host. Without this change it's impossible to find out which processes

commit_message:
Use transient systemd units in Process fixture

This makes the damon processes spawned by fullstack tests more similar
to those used in a real deployment. It creates a systemd unit for each
daemon on the fly and combines all daemons of the same host in a systemd
slice. The units are automatically removed on service shutdown.

This also better ensures that there are no left over processes after
failed test cases as all processes started in a systemd unit are cleaned
up when the unit is stopped.

This change is a prerequisite to implement methods to kill or shutdown a
host. Without this change it's impossible to find out which processes
belong to a agent and to kill all these processes. This is important to
eg. kill keepalived processes started by L3 agents.

The timeout for the L2 agent restart has to be extended slightly because
the service is no longer killed with SIGKILL but properly shut down.

Change-Id: Ieb21de8a370aca24abc216f55dbd98e553a65d05

commit_message:
Fix skyline user creation

With previous change [1] when type of role name was changed from string
to a list, variable name change was not reflected in _service_users,
which leads to skipping creation and role assignment to users.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_skyline/+/918160

Change-Id: Ib5a4af5ea79868b7dd7ee7f4329317815f3b466a

commit_message:
Support collecting libvirt domain logs

This makes use of the linked kolla patch which exposes the logs
in /var/log/kolla. The log file is some what unstructured, so
we are using the concat filter to merge some output that is split
over serveral lines.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/905580
Partial-Bug: #2049389
Change-Id: I0b36d3338d5dc6f553aba3ac631832b549b5ca68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/90/905590/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <source> @type tail path /var/log/kolla/libvirt/qemu/*.log pos_file /var/run/{{ fluentd_binary }}/libvirt-domain.pos tag infra.libvirt.domain format none path_key path keep_time_key false enable_watch_timer false </source>

commit_message:
Support collecting libvirt qemu domain logs

This change causes the logs to be collected in /var/log/kolla.
Unfortuantly, it was not possible to change the log directory via a
config option, so we need to symlink the hardcoded path to a directory
under /var/log/kolla. The consequence of this is that the logs are
collected in the kolla logs volume where other programs, such as
fluentd, can read them.

Change-Id: If10006bf7f037a44b9b664b70ad423f7c6c08f45
Partial-Bug: #2049389

subject: ml2/ovs: avoid reconfig bridges/flows when reconnecting to OVS
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-05-30 10:17:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1bde68b0e694284a90d42d3a187b381693dc2c70', 'message': 'ml2/ovs: avoid reconfig bridges/flows when reconnecting to OVS

The RPC loop handles the case when the agent loses its connection to
OVS. Currently, it waits until the connection is reestablished but
does not handle cleaning up events added by OVS notifications
regarding bridges. This results in a complete recomputation of the

This fix ensures that `bridges_added` events from the monitor are
cleaned up after waiting for a reconnection, preventing unnecessary

commit_message:
ml2/ovs: avoid reconfig bridges/flows when reconnecting to OVS

The RPC loop handles the case when the agent loses its connection to
OVS. Currently, it waits until the connection is reestablished but
does not handle cleaning up events added by OVS notifications
regarding bridges. This results in a complete recomputation of the
flows.

This fix ensures that `bridges_added` events from the monitor are
cleaned up after waiting for a reconnection, preventing unnecessary
reconfiguration of physical bridges and flows.

Related-Bug: #1813703
Related-Bug: #1813705
Related-Bug: #1813707

commit_message:
Add more metadata to volume.size and volume.backup.size pollster

When events are received from cinder, this includes the the volume_type_id
field (and not the volume_type name). Since Wallaby version it is now
possible to fetch this id from the API, so we can now make this poller
consistent with what is sent over the notification bus.

Another useful missing field for backups is the is_incremental field.

As the backup.user_id field was added in microversion 3.56, it makes sense
to add this information here as well to make it consistent with other
samples.

Closes-bug: #2064290
Change-Id: Ib109f399bab43ed8a6a0e0afea27ff0e5f7ae883
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/14/917714/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'volume_type_id', 'is_incremental', user_id=backup.user_id,

commit_message:
Remove old horizon base mapping

In case of environment upgrades, with they want to enable Skyline
dashboard after upgrade, we need to ensure that old horizon mapping
with higher priority is removed first.
Otherwise it will lead to incorrect behaviour of Skyline/Horizon.

I do not push this to master, as this is only relevant for upgrades to
2024.1. Upgrade to 2024.2 is supported only from 2024.1, where it will
already be covered.

Change-Id: I13c4d874b6c99732758628313188b60ad7d85c4d

commit_message:
CI: drop RMQ reconfigure step in queue migrations

When migrating to quorum queues, the RabbitMQ configuration itself
remains unchanged. This step can therefore be dropped.

Closes-Bug: #2058512

Change-Id: I7995a0540066220feda9ef827a06b17fa960f49c

commit_message:
Define region and interface for collector/fetcher

It appears, that produced gnocchiclient does not respect region_name
from the auth_section, thus it needs to be defined directly for the
fetcher.

We align collector for now with fetcher, to make change backportable.

Closes-Bug: #2067084
Change-Id: If3a37b6190449e18446e65ce3b8cb70cd9038c37
(cherry picked from commit fae91db568637021438ffe436fb935a6735feb66)

commit_message:
Add L3 HA fullstack failover tests

* Generate unique internal and external router device names
  using the agent's hostname. This is to allow multiple HA
  router replicas to co-exist on the same machine, otherwise
  they'd all use the same device names and OVS would freak out.
* Add host.disconnect method that disconnects the host from
  the central internal and external bridges, simulating pulling
  the cable from the host's NIC.
* Add host.kill and host.shutdown methods to forcefully kill and
  gracefully shutdown a host simulating a host failure and host
  shutdown.
* Added a L3 HA failover test for graceful failover, host failure and
  network disconnect.

Co-Authored-By: Assaf Muller <amuller@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Iaaa1c2cab0341a929e368392aa7dc47c9b2399c2
Original-Change-Id: I250fa41d89dfc4f9f3ba4c03a027b52b2e8c4b4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/29/917429/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.tests.common import net_helpers l3_agents = [host.agents['l3'] for host in self.environment.hosts if 'l3' in host.agents] # Two hosts with L3 agent to host HA routers # Add two hosts for FakeFullstackMachines host_descriptions.extend([ environment.HostDescription() for _ in range(2) ]) def _get_host_for_active_ha_router_replica(self, router_id): result = self.client.list_l3_agent_hosting_routers(router_id) hostname = next( agent['host'] for agent in result['agents'] if agent['ha_state'] == 'active') return self.environment.get_host_by_name(hostname) def test_ha_router_failover(self): tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() # Create router router = self.safe_client.create_router(tenant_id, ha=True) router_id = router['id'] agents = self.client.list_l3_agent_hosting_routers(router_id) self.assertEqual(2, len(agents['agents']), 'HA router must be scheduled to both nodes') # Create internal subnet network = self.safe_client.create_network(tenant_id) subnet = self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, network['id'], '20.0.0.0/24') self.safe_client.add_router_interface(router_id, subnet['id']) # Create external network external_network = self.safe_client.create_network( tenant_id, external=True) self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, external_network['id'], '42.0.0.0/24', enable_dhcp=False) self.safe_client.add_gateway_router( router_id, external_network['id']) # Create internal VM vm = self.useFixture( machine.FakeFullstackMachine( self.environment.hosts[2], network['id'], tenant_id, self.safe_client)) vm.block_until_boot() # Create external VM external = self.useFixture( machine.FakeFullstackMachine( self.environment.hosts[3], external_network['id'], tenant_id, self.safe_client)) external.block_until_boot() common_utils.wait_until_true( functools.partial( self._is_ha_router_active_on_one_agent, router_id), timeout=90) # Test external connectivity, failover, test again pinger = net_helpers.Pinger(vm.namespace, external.ip, interval=0.1) pinger.start() # Ensure connectivity before disconnect vm.block_until_ping(external.ip) active_host = self._get_host_for_active_ha_router_replica(router_id) active_host.disconnect() # Ensure connectivity is shortly lost on failover and recovers vm.assert_no_ping(external.ip) vm.block_until_ping(external.ip) pinger.stop() # With the default advert_int of 2s the keepalived master timeout is # about 6s. Assert less than 80 lost packets (9 seconds) lost = pinger.sent - pinger.received message = (f'Sent {pinger.sent} packets, received {pinger.received} ' f'packets, lost {lost} packets') assert lost < 90, message

Dnsmasq doesn't seem to want to start without this capability.

subject: Refactor Neutron L3 agent restart handler
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-12-20 15:40:12.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/neutron/handlers/main.yml', 'releasenotes/notes/bug-2047045-ce3c11ab6cae102.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/973395b10e9284f9b0f41761b5e990268eba48e0', 'message': 'Refactor Neutron L3 agent restart handler

Previously, each host would have run a task for every host which is both
confusing and exhausts the available forks (if the number of forks is
less than the number of hosts being targetted) causing excessive delays.

This change ensures that only two tasks run per host. The first will
restart the container and the second will be skipped but allows us to
add a delay between this and the subsequent restart.

Refactoring the handler to work this way allows it to keep the delay
specified in neutron_l3_agent_failover_delay but only create a number of
tasks equal to 2*compute_nodes rather than compute_nodes^2 avoiding
exhaustion of available forks.

Closes-Bug: #2047045
Change-Id: I026349aea2906828164116f652093718267e5732
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor Neutron L3 agent restart handler

Previously, each host would have run a task for every host which is both
confusing and exhausts the available forks (if the number of forks is
less than the number of hosts being targetted) causing excessive delays.

This change ensures that only two tasks run per host. The first will
restart the container and the second will be skipped but allows us to
add a delay between this and the subsequent restart.

Refactoring the handler to work this way allows it to keep the delay
specified in neutron_l3_agent_failover_delay but only create a number of
tasks equal to 2*compute_nodes rather than compute_nodes^2 avoiding
exhaustion of available forks.

Closes-Bug: #2047045
Change-Id: I026349aea2906828164116f652093718267e5732
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/34/904134/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/2047045 Avoid increasing delays between Neutron L3 agent restarts if the number of forks is less than the number of compute nodes being targetted. `LP#[2047045] <https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/2047045>`__

commit_message:
Bump SQLAlchemy requirement

This is primarily to fix the requirements-check job, which is failing
following the removal of excluded versions [1]:

    ERROR: Requirement for package SQLAlchemy excludes a version not excluded in the global list.
      Local settings : {'!=1.1.6', '!=1.1.7', '!=1.1.5', '!=1.1.8'}
      Global settings: set()
      Unexpected     : {'!=1.1.6', '!=1.1.7', '!=1.1.5', '!=1.1.8'}

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/requirements/+/879743

Change-Id: Id9a59c3ac040a5fc2069fb1d1b592e36fdfdd3a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/blazar refs/changes/51/920851/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
When we failed to load pkcs12 cert print warning

Print actual error when we failed to load pkcs12 cert and
falling back to the default implemntation, as exception may
not be related to certificate or its format like an issue
with wrong methods during cryptography version mismatch

*** AttributeError: module 'OpenSSL.crypto' has no attribute 'load_pkcs12'

Related-Prod: PRODX-39931
Change-Id: I85c8a615c4f2e08e28939805ae0e9b2028dadaed
(cherry picked from commit 96846e7b66f50ed0af7ce99f547e7d2e9cb2cda6)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/56/917456/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except Exception as e: LOG.warning('Failed to load PKCS12Cert for secret %s with %s', cert_ref, str(e)) LOG.warning('Falling back to the barbican_legacy implementation.')

commit_message:
Add ingress deamon

Adds ingress deamon, for 18.0+ Ceph versions
Enables logging for ceph mds

Change-Id: Ic345784873161df2326344c8993f5691fbadb40c
Depends-On: Idf15ccf996eb6cdc05a960bdc6411f6fdb9e5fea
Depends-On: I85ad659bf1ad36cb5340a53cd57603451fc77147
Depends-On: I5b7fd5b2b557203189c25fa2a988d790e7fda3eb
(cherry picked from commit a42ee1269b6d33094156690836d4600c9b7705ee)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph refs/changes/40/908940/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: VIP=$HOST_IP# Get Ceph version function _get_ceph_version { local ceph_version_str ceph_version_str=$(sudo podman run --rm --entrypoint ceph $CONTAINER_IMAGE \ --version | awk '{ print $3 }') echo $ceph_version_str } local ceph_version ceph_version=$(_get_ceph_version) if [ "${ceph_version%%\.*}" -ge 18 ]; then $SUDO "$CEPHADM" shell --fsid $FSID --config $CEPH_CONFIG \ --keyring $CEPH_KEYRING -- ceph nfs cluster create \ "$FSNAME" "$HOSTNAME" --port $NFS_PORT --ingress \ --ingress-mode haproxy-protocol --virtual_ip $HOST_IP else echo "[CEPHADM] Ingress service is not deployed \ to preserve the ability to apply client restrictions." $SUDO "$CEPHADM" shell --fsid $FSID --config $CEPH_CONFIG \ --keyring $CEPH_KEYRING -- ceph nfs cluster create \ "$FSNAME" "$HOSTNAME" --port $NFS_PORT fi
deleted_lines: # (fpantano) TODO: Build an ingress daemon on top of this $SUDO "$CEPHADM" shell --fsid $FSID --config $CEPH_CONFIG \ --keyring $CEPH_KEYRING -- ceph orch apply nfs \ "$FSNAME" --placement="$HOSTNAME" --port $NFS_PORT

commit_message:
Add Redis as caching backend for Placement

Openstack supports Redis as the caching backend,
however there is no such function in Kolla Ansible.
Redis has many advantages to Memcached, for example
TLS suport.  This commit introduces Redis caching
backend for Placement.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/909188

Change-Id: I72eb3051ca35968f7b2448f0d563d8f6e9912ec0

commit_message:
Bump Ansible version for tests repo

Current Ansible version for tests repo, which is used for functional
tests can not deal with some more modern logic, causing CI to fail
for Ubuntu Jammy on apt_package_pinning for Galera role.

Updating Ansible version fixes the issue.

Change-Id: I70838dc4fb1cadfcf579b5e9af5769a8f48108da

commit_message:
Use built-in json module

The simplejson library has been generally used in OpenStack in the past
to implement compatibility with Python 2 and Python 3. However now
python 2 is no longer supported, and we can use the built-in json
module.

Note that the built-in json module does not accept byte values, while
these were automatically decoded by simplejson using utf-8 encoding.
Add encoding option to all subprocess calls so that outputs are all
encoded strings and can be passed directly into json data.

Change-Id: Ibfd47e87994511198d8883a91978be542dac3a3e

commit_message:
s3api: Add MPU uploadId to logs

Use the same swift.log_info environment key we use for some extra
container-sync and x-delete-at information.

Change-Id: I14e1beba652a1ac3a7690381dd6ad3602a619503

commit_message:
improve volume support in nova driver

This commit introduces the following changes:
 - Support for VMs that have been booted from OpenStack volumes
 - Support for VMs that have been booted from OpenStack volume snapshots
 - New Nova driver functionality to be able to traverse volume chains
   in order to find the bootable root image of given chain.
 - Customizable volume chain traversal depth via configuration variable
   SUSHY_MAX_VOLUME_DEPTH (default 15)

Closes-Bug: #2067405
Change-Id: I5d46ee94d22e7c0913305070e366e4b06226dc5b
Signed-off-by: Adam Rozman <adam.rozman@est.tech>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-tools refs/changes/13/912113/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NO_VOL_TRAVERSE = 'N/A unable to traverse volume chain of the boot volume' MULTY_BOOT_VOL = 'N/A possibly multiple bootable volumes are attached' def _get_volume_by_id(self, volume_id): return self._cc.get_volume_by_id(volume_id) def _get_boot_image_of_volume(self, volume): volume_id = volume.get("id") self._logger.debug("check boot image of volume: " + volume_id) volume_image_metadata = volume.get('volume_image_metadata') image_id = volume_image_metadata.get('image_id') self._logger.debug("boot image id is: " + str(image_id)) return self._cc.get_image_by_id(image_id) if image_id else None def _get_source_volume_of_volume(self, volume): self._logger.debug("Looking for source volume of volume!") source_volume_id = volume.get('source_volume_id') self._logger.debug("Source volumeid is: " + source_volume_id) if source_volume_id: return self._cc.get_volume_by_id(source_volume_id) return None def _get_source_volume_by_snapshot(self, volume): snapshot_id = volume.get('snapshot_id') snapshot = None volume_id = None if snapshot_id: snapshot = self._cc.get_volume_snapshot_by_id(snapshot_id) else: return None if snapshot: volume_id = snapshot.get('volume_id') else: return None if volume_id: return self._cc.get_volume_by_id(volume_id) return None can't be dedtermined. Valid values are: *Pxe*, *Hdd*, *Cd*. def _get_vol_boot_image(self, volume): """Get the boot image of a volume This function traverse the chain of source_volumes and snapshots to a predetermined depth of instances in case there was no image_id found for the volume. The maximum depth of the traversal process is specified by the "SUSHY_MAX_VOLUME_DEPTH" parameter in the configuration file. :param volume: volume object under analysis :returns: properties dict of the volume's boot image """ max_depth = int(self._config.get('SUSHY_MAX_VOLUME_DEPTH', '15')) current = volume boot_image = None source = None for i in range(max_depth): boot_image = self._get_boot_image_of_volume(current) # If boot image was found exit the traversal process if boot_image: break source = self._get_source_volume_of_volume(current) if not source: source = self._get_source_volume_by_snapshot(current) # Unable to find either source volume or snapshot, chain breaks if not source: errmsg = "Unable to find the boot image!" raise error.NotFound(errmsg) # Traversal step succeds source volume was found # No boot image was found in current volume keep traversing current = source source = None # Traversal completed but traversal depth was to shallow return boot_image def _get_vol_hw_firmware_type(self, volume): """Determine the boot mode used for a volume This function determines the hw_firmware_data after figuring out what was the original image used to create the volume under analysis. :param volume: volume object under analysis :returns: hw_frimware_type of underlying image """ boot_image = self._get_vol_boot_image(volume) if not boot_image: return None image_properties = boot_image.get('properties') self._logger.debug("boot image props: " + str(image_properties)) if image_properties: hw_fmw_type = image_properties.get('hw_firmware_type') self._logger.debug("hw fmw type: " + str(hw_fmw_type)) return hw_fmw_type return None def _get_vol_secure_boot(self, volume): """Determine the boot mode used for a volume This function determines the hw_firmware_data after figuring out what was the original image used to create the volume under analysis. :param volume: volume object under analysis :returns: hw_frimware_type of underlying image """ boot_image = self._get_vol_boot_image(volume) if not boot_image: return None image_properties = boot_image.get('properties') self._logger.debug("boot image props: " + str(image_properties)) if image_properties: os_sec_boot = image_properties.get('os_secure_boot') return os_sec_boot return None def _get_instance_bootable_volume(self, instance): """Get the only bootable volume of an instance :param instance: instance under analysis :return: the only bootable volume or None if there is none :raises FishyError: when there are multiple bootable volumes """ volume_records = instance.get('attached_volumes') boot_volume = None num_boot_volume = 0 if not volume_records: return None for volume_record in volume_records: volume_id = volume_record.get('id') if not volume_id: continue volume = self._get_volume_by_id(volume_id) if not volume: continue if volume.get('is_bootable'): boot_volume = volume num_boot_volume = num_boot_volume + 1 self._logger.debug("Bootable volume was found!") if num_boot_volume > 1: # In case of multiple bootable volumes boot order can't be # determined errmsg = "There is more than 1 bootable volume attached!" raise error.FishyError(errmsg) return boot_volume def _get_instance_secure_boot_by_id(self, identity): """Return the raw secure boot config status based on VM id This function will analyze both the attached images and volumes to find the boot image and then check the boot image's secure boot. If there are both a bootable volume and a boot image directly attached to the VM then the boot image has precedence over the volume. :param identity: id of the VM :return: relevant os_secure_boot propety value (str or None) """ instance = self._get_instance(identity) secure_boot = None try: # Check if the machine was booted from image image_id = instance.get('image_id') boot_image = self._get_image_info(image_id) image_properties = boot_image.get('image_properties') secure_boot = image_properties.get('os_secure_boot') return secure_boot except Exception as error: emsg = str(error) self._logger.debug(emsg) # If the instance was not directly booted from image or there are # issues with the image reference then check whether the machine was # booted from volume and traverse the volume chain if needed boot_volume = self._get_instance_bootable_volume(instance) if boot_volume: secure_boot_mode = self._get_vol_secure_boot(boot_volume) return secure_boot_mode :returns: either *UEFI* or *Legacy* as `str` :rasies: 404 if the boot mode can't be determined :raises: 500 if there are multiple boot_mode = None try: # Check if the machine was booted from image image_id = instance.get('image_id') boot_image = self._get_image_info(image_id) image_properties = boot_image.get('properties') hw_fmw_type = image_properties.get('hw_firmware_type') boot_mode = self.BOOT_MODE_MAP_REV.get(hw_fmw_type) except Exception as error: emsg = "Error while checking image attached to VM: " + str(error) self._logger.debug(emsg) if boot_mode: return boot_mode # If the instance was not directly booted from image or there are # issues with the image reference then check whether the machine was # booted from volume and traverse the volume chain if needed boot_volume = self._get_instance_bootable_volume(instance) errmsg = "Boot mode was not found!" if not boot_volume: raise error.NotFound(errmsg) hw_fmw_type = self._get_vol_hw_firmware_type(boot_volume) if not hw_fmw_type: raise error.NotFound(errmsg) boot_mode = self.BOOT_MODE_MAP_REV.get(hw_fmw_type) if not boot_mode: raise error.NotFound(errmsg) return boot_mode boot_mode = self.get_boot_mode(identity) if boot_mode != 'UEFI': msg = "Boot mode does not support secure boot" sec_boot_supported = self._get_instance_secure_boot(identity) if not sec_boot_supported: errmsg = "Secure boot support can't be determined!" raise error.NotFound(errmsg) elif sec_boot_supported == 'required': return True return False
deleted_lines: can't be determined. Valid values are: *Pxe*, *Hdd*, *Cd*. :returns: either *UEFI* or *Legacy* as `str` or `None` if current boot mode can't be determined image = self._get_image_info(instance.image['id']) hw_firmware_type = getattr(image, 'hw_firmware_type', None) return self.BOOT_MODE_MAP_REV.get(hw_firmware_type) if self.get_boot_mode(identity) == 'Legacy': msg = 'Legacy boot mode does not support secure boot' instance = self._get_instance(identity) image = self._get_image_info(instance.image['id']) return getattr(image, 'os_secure_boot', None) == 'required'

commit_message:
Pin requests to <2.32 for docker sdk (2023.1 and older releases)

As 2023.1 and older releases have docker>=3.0.0,<7.0.0 we need
to pin requests to <2.32 due too [1]

Also marking collectd as unbuildable to unblock CI [2]

[1] https://github.com/docker/docker-py/issues/3256
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/918962

Related-Bug: #2066364
Related-Bug: #2065362

commit_message:
Pin requests to <2.32 for docker sdk (2023.1 and older releases)

As 2023.1 and older releases have docker>=3.0.0,<7.0.0 we need
to pin requests to <2.32 due too [1]

Also marking collectd as unbuildable to unblock CI [2],
furthermore dropping centos8 CI jobs, as it went EOL.

[1] https://github.com/docker/docker-py/issues/3256
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/918962

Related-Bug: #2066364
Related-Bug: #2065362

Change-Id: Ic298d9eb9d73ee4378921e15865ec11a488f7bd0
(cherry picked from commit b5c936a3a564e10b35b0e378bd6d5034f0db93b4)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-06-05 17:19:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sunbeam-charms/commit/e3f00a64d8d672cc8ddaa4d6919335c1c7a431ed', 'message': '[all] only publish active status at the end of the hook

commit_message:
[all] only publish active status at the end of the hook

The status_compound by designed set the unit's status many times during
hook execution. The unit's status is directly published to the
controller. This leads to outside observers seeing active status (and
lot of chatter around statuses) when the unit is in fact not ready.

With this change, units will only publish an active status at the end of
the hook execution. All other levels are still directly published to the
controller.
Units will no longer publish the WaitingStatus("no status yet"). This
creates a lot of chatter and holds little value.

Re-organize keystone __init__ not to publish false `Service not
bootstrap` status.

Closes-Bug: #2067016
Change-Id: Ie73b95972a44833ba4509f8fd2c2f52ed476004d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sunbeam-charms refs/changes/01/921401/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove SQLAlchemy tips jobs

The most recent SQLAlchemy and Alembic versions are now in
upper-constraints. As a result, this job has served its purpose and can
be removed. For more information, see [1].

[1] https://lists.openstack.org/archives/list/openstack-discuss@lists.openstack.org/thread/RBHXHTO3GUOOXVSZXD4C2O3TKDOH2QSC/

Co-Authored-By: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/requirements/+/879743
Change-Id: Ia5ba48aa27b537e556d56d270af126e223d0f626

commit_message:
Remove deprecated [health_manager] health_update_driver

The option was deprecated in Victoria release[1] and has had no effect
since then.

Also remove the deprecated [health_manager] stats_update_driver option
which was renamed by the same commit.

[1] 5092597f6b78bc3f02812cd425aa9d95e9501be7

Change-Id: I690428bae49dc594eacae08d40612e4d1f7523a1

so the related jobs must be adopted.

subject: Handle Power On/Off for child node cases
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-09-26 16:34:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/9b98747d0d038aa03a7dd84ddc1c736b13d12eba', 'message': 'WIP: Assume the parent node needs to be powered on

So, there are cases where say you may have multiple DPUs in a
physical server, each card when fully operating can consume 100-150
watts. In some cases, these cards can have external power supplies,
but need the physical host in a running power-on state in order for
the device to be powered on.

This is realistically a fix we should backport once we sort
through the details, if we agree this makes sense to do, as is.

So, there are cases where say you may have multiple DPUs in a
physical server, each card when fully operating can consume 100-150
watts. In some cases, these cards can have external power supplies,
but need the physical host in a running power-on state in order for
the device to be powered on.

Conversely, we also now power off the child nodes if the parent
node has been requested to be powered off, since we *really* don't
want cause inadvertent harm to the child node.

This is realistically a fix we should backport once we sort
through the details, if we agree this makes sense to do, as is.

Change-Id: Ib2bfe04cdaa82264ba8bb1e71477899bb6268179

commit_message:
Handle Power On/Off for child node cases

So, there are cases where say you may have multiple DPUs in a
physical server, each card when fully operating can consume 100-150
watts. In some cases, these cards can have external power supplies,
but need the physical host in a running power-on state in order for
the device to be powered on.

Conversely, we also now power off the child nodes if the parent
node has been requested to be powered off, since we *really* don't
want cause inadvertent harm to the child node.

This is realistically a fix we should backport once we sort
through the details, if we agree this makes sense to do, as is.

Change-Id: Ib2bfe04cdaa82264ba8bb1e71477899bb6268179

commit_message:
Assert URL consistency for agent_url

While agent_url is software generated, it is still a public endpoint
and at least needs some upfront filtering applied. To do this, we
can leverage urllib in the standard library to disassemble the
url, and reconstruct it based upon the standards. The plus of this
approach is that it will remove some invalid formatting for us, and
if things are too out of line, an exception is raised as ValueError.

An important note, this is *not* explicitly urlparsing security[0] as
denoted in the Python urllib documentation, but that the application
should operate defensively.

[0]: https://docs.python.org/3/library/urllib.parse.html#url-parsing-security

Change-Id: I45ee1c8a73ed13511bc47a69130105f16d34be1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/94/921294/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from urllib import parse as urlparse try: # NOTE(TheJulia): Use of urllib.urlparse is not a security # guard, but detecting oddities and incorrect formatting # https://docs.python.org/3/library/urllib.parse.html#url-parsing-security # noqa parsed_url = urlparse.urlparse(callback_url) # Check if http (compatability), or https (much newer agents) if 'http' not in parsed_url.scheme: raise ValueError callback_url = parsed_url.geturl() except ValueError: raise exception.InvalidParameterValue( _('An issue with the supplied "callback_url" has been ' 'detected.'))

commit_message:
Excise use of non-timezone aware utcnow()

Replace all instances of `datetime.datetime.utcnow()`,
which is deprecated, with the timezone-aware oslo's
`timeutils.utcnow()` method, across the Ironic project.

Closes-Bug: #2067740
Change-Id: I998681c14f945846f58e723b9be2202dbe8ea12c

commit_message:
Fix leak of ports on share server deletion

- Manila share server deletion happens asynchronously. If deletion of
share server fails in between, share server network ports remained as
it is. So we should better delete share network ports first and then
continue share server deletion.
- It may be possible, that there are ports existing without a
corresponding manila network allocation entry in the manila db, because
port create request may have been successfully sent to neutron, but not
stored in db. So query(and delete) those from neutron after db entries
are deleted.

Closes-bug: #2067266
Change-Id: Id86dade1194494e599aea9adad06e4ca6cb119b6
(cherry picked from commit 76d032969848fa409f3b7da499cc2da3de67f6be)

commit_message:
[doc] Properly promote deploy guide

By mistake in [1] promote job has been replaced with build job, which
leaded to broken promote process of docs.

Here we introduce new promote job for deploy guide, that is a child
of openstack promote job.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/920043

Change-Id: Ia26ae735bdfffb8cc76a2326758f410a561ba868

commit_message:
kolla-ansible now uses default inventory file

Commit 6c72fa811739573c502240d9ee93bf1823d20447 changed kolla-ansible's
behavior regarding default inventory. This commit restores that behavior
by using the default inventory if no other one was specified on the
command line.

Closes-Bug: #2058759
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla/+/920279?forceReload=true

Change-Id: Ia6439e8861612063e37dea784d65ae343d87fae8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/93/913993/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # If no inventory has been specified then use the default one if [ -z "${INVENTORIES}" ]; then INVENTORIES="${INVENTORY}" fi

commit_message:
Self-Service via Runbooks

Spec for step runbooks

Partial-bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/2027690
Change-Id: Iee77a73e7acc0053632646de7bc96ada090f7641
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/64/890164/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================== Self-Service via Templates ========================== https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/2027690 With the addition of service steps, combined with owner/lessee, we now have an opportunity to allow project members to self-serve many maintenance items by permitting them access to curated templates. This feature will primarily involve extending deploy templates to work with any step-based flow and adding project awareness to those templates. Problem description =================== Currently, project members have limited ability to self-serve maintenance items. Ironic operators are given the difficult choice of giving project members broad access to nodes, allowing them to run arbitrary manual cleaning or service steps with the only alternative being permitting no access to self-serve these scheduled maintenance items. Additionally, while we have a general concept of deploy templates, there is no mechanism to template other step-based actions, such as service or manual cleaning. Use cases for this would include: - A project member with a downtime-sensitive cluster can coordinate upgrades on a running cluster, integrating calls to Ironic to upgrade the firmware with calls to their cluster to "up" and "down" nodes appropriately. - A lower-privileged operations team can be given templates-as-runbooks to run in manual cleaning to resolve issues, without giving them the ability to do anything non-prescribed by the cluster admins. Proposed change =============== The proposed change is to use the existing deploy_templates model and extend it to work with any step-based flow. This will allow us to template manual cleaning, service steps, and any other future step-based flows. Additionally, we will extend that model to include information about if a template is public and what project it belongs to. Additionally, we will ensure that the full CRUD lifecycle of templates is made role-aware in the code, so that a project can limit who can create, delete, edit, or mark templates as public all as separate policy toggles. Alternatives ------------ There are likely other ways to achieve the same goal. None have been proposed. Data model impact ----------------- The existing deploy_templates table will be renamed to templates. Two new fields will be added to it: - public (bool) - project (string, usually a keystone project ID) State Machine Impact -------------------- While no states or state transitions are being proposed, the APIs to invoke some of those state transitions will need to change to become template-aware. REST API impact --------------- NOTE(JayF): Is it right to make it keep working on the old URL? Should we just force the new name based on advertised API version in request header? Seems like keeping both plumbed is easier+kinder to opers. The existing REST API endpoints related to deploy templates will be renamed from deploy_templates to templates. The endpoints will also continue to be available under the old names for backwards compatibility. Additionally, we will limit these API endpoints with policy checks, based on the value of template.public and template.project. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- The CLI will be updated to understand the changes made to the template API endpoints. The CLI will also perform the rename in the same manner: - "baremetal deploy template list" would rename to "baremetal template list" - The old name would continue to work for backwards compatibility. RPC API impact -------------- Yes, I think. Unsure exactly what/how yet. Note from julia: the request context won't be in the task past the initial request, so we'll need to save it as a dict (I think this will be in RPC API) Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Ramdisk impact -------------- None Security impact --------------- Operators are warned that even with use of this feature, users may be able to leverage steps or access which are innoculous on their own, but malicious when combined. For example, a project member with both access to run a service step template containing in-band steps, and also with access to update a node's deploy_ramdisk could combine those two pieces of access to run arbitrary code. Ensure you have reviewed all possible threat models when granting additional access to less-trusted individuals. Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: JayF <jay@jvf.cc> Other contributors: You <please@for.me.example.com> Work Items ---------- - Rename DeployTemplates to Templates - Object layer - DB layer - API layer - Add new fields to Templates table - Add policy-awareness to /v1/templates Dependencies ============ While it doesn't directly depend on it, this will not be incredibly useful service steps is complete, and thereby shouldn't be started until it's merged. Testing ======= Unit tests will be added to test the new functionality. Integration tests will be added to test the new API endpoints and CLI commands. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== The changes are backwards compatible. Existing templates will continue to function as before. Existing API endpoints will continue to function as before. Documentation Impact ==================== The new functionality will need to be documented. This includes documentation for the new API endpoints and CLI commands, as well as documenting security caveats detailed above. References ========== None

commit_message:
Fix regex lines in zuul.d/* files

Commit 260c968118934 broke the gate by causing jobs
to not get run when it added RE2 compatibility for
irrelevant-files. Digging found that RE2 doesn't
support negative lookahead (and won't ever), so it's
impossible to replace the previous pcre filter with a
similar RE2 filter.

Instead of reverting to the original filter, which
is considered obsolete by zuul, this patch fixes the
issue by explicitly listing all files under zuul.d/
except the one that we actually want to trigger the
jobs: zuul.d/project.yaml.

Listing all the files in the directory for every job
is not ideal, and we may revisit it later, or perhaps
even reconsider the extensive use of irrelevant-files
in the neutron tree. This will have to wait for when
the gate is in better shape though.

[0] https://github.com/google/re2/issues/156

Related-bug: #2065821
Change-Id: I3bba89ac14414c6b7d375072ae92d2e0b5497736

commit_message:
Add some swap to tox-cover job

As mentioned in the related bug we are seeing
hign memory usage in the job since sqlalchemy
bump to 2.0 and this leads to gate instability.
Adding some swap to handle this until the issue
is fixed.

Also reverts the concurrency reduction change[1]
that was done for this issue as that shouldn't be
needed now.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/920766
Related-Bug: #2065821

Change-Id: I33c4869c1d5230c0c8cc2f0dd4f6d071600bf220
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/20/921420/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pre-run: playbooks/configure_swap.yaml vars: configure_swap_size: 4096

commit_message:
Replace hardcoded BiosVersion with an updatable field

Currently, BiosVersion value returned in respose to GET /System/
comes from a value hardcoded in template. This change replaces the
hardcoded value with a variable stored in sushy:bios metadata in the
libvirt xml definition of the VM.

Change-Id: Iaefc695c6cb177bc232112515c7b33c7b9af8b68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-tools refs/changes/87/909487/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DEFAULT_BIOS_ATTRIBUTES = {"BiosVersion": "1.0.0", "BootMode": "Uefi",

commit_message:
Remove special treatment of .json for API objects

- /v1/nodes/test.json will now only mean node with the name
"test.json"
- /v1/nodes/test.json.json will mean a node with the name
"test.json.json" and,
- /v1/nodes/test will mean a node with the name "test".

So /v1/nodes/test.json will no longer default to "test" and
will HTTP 404 unless a node with the name "test" actually exists.

This also removes the backward compatibility with the
guess_content_type_from_ext feature

Closes-Bug: #1748224

Change-Id: If4b3a23e2a09065f5e063e66cff66b96af4d3393
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/67/913467/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log from ironic.common import utils LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class JsonExtensionMiddleware(object): """Simplified processing of .json extension. Previously Ironic API used the "guess_content_type_from_ext" feature. It was never needed, as we never allowed non-JSON content types anyway. Now that it is removed, this middleware strips .json extension for backward compatibility. """ def __init__(self, app): self.app = app def __call__(self, env, start_response): path = utils.safe_rstrip(env.get('PATH_INFO'), '/') if path and path.endswith('.json'): LOG.debug('Stripping .json prefix from %s for compatibility ' 'with pecan', path) env['PATH_INFO'] = path[:-5] env['HAS_JSON_SUFFIX'] = True else: env['HAS_JSON_SUFFIX'] = False return self.app(env, start_response)

commit_message:
Enable RabbitMQ feature flags pre-upgrade

This task must be carried out before any RabbitMQ instances are
stopped, so must live in the playbook as opposed to the role.

This complements the post-upgrade enablement which happens within
the role itself, and covers the case where older versions of the
role have not already enabled the relevant flags.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server/+/920999
Change-Id: Idf33b6810e1afb3a89dad5e65a48e86ac0a58a67
(cherry picked from commit 6a21e2e2676f6637330bd22ee64ef8f58c5f73e0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/00/921000/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Stable feature flags must be enabled pre-upgrade # https://www.rabbitmq.com/docs/feature-flags#version-compatibility - name: Enable stable feature flags pre-upgrade hosts: "{{ rabbitmq_host_group | default('rabbitmq_all') }}[0]" gather_facts: false user: root tasks: - name: Running feature flags tasks from the role import_role: name: rabbitmq_server tasks_from: rabbitmq_feature_flags.yml when: rabbitmq_upgrade | default(false) | bool

subject: Add typing information to octavia.amphorae package
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2024-01-10 08:40:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/4ba3705583cdd12ac94607e65daae1f292f335ec', 'message': 'Add typing information to octavia.amphorae package

Apart from the benefit of finding possible bugs using mypy,
type annotations also have other benefits like for instance:

- IDEs like PyCharm and VS Code can use annotations to provide
  better
  code completion, highlight errors and to make coding more efficient
- It serves as documentation of the code and helps to understand
  code
  better. The annotation syntax is very easy to read.
- Sphinx generated module documentation can use this information
  (without the need for additional type info in comments/docstrings)

The syntax used here should be supported by Python 3.6, so it should
not create issues when backporting patches in the future.

Partial-Bug: #2017974
Change-Id: I5b0f084785f477c855218c54a21caecdecefb62f

commit_message:
Add typing information to octavia.amphorae package

... and fix issues reported by mypy.

Apart from the benefit of finding possible bugs using mypy,
type annotations also have other benefits like for instance:

- IDEs like PyCharm and VS Code can use annotations to provide
  better
  code completion, highlight errors and to make coding more efficient
- It serves as documentation of the code and helps to understand
  code
  better. The annotation syntax is very easy to read.
- Sphinx generated module documentation can use this information
  (without the need for additional type info in comments/docstrings)

The syntax used here should be supported by Python 3.6, so it should
not create issues when backporting patches in the future.

Partial-Bug: #2017974
Change-Id: I5b0f084785f477c855218c54a21caecdecefb62f
